general_course_objectives:
To give participants experience of integrated building design, and
how specialised competences can be used in collaboration within
multidisciplinary project teams to create a design fulfilling many
functional requirements at the same time. In this course, you are
working with the additional competences it takes to construct
solutions to open ended problems compared with only being able to
analyse a given construction. The course is based on solving in a
complex and realistic design problem in groups which is in line
with the demands given by the construction industry.
learning_objectives:
A student who has met the objectives of the course will be able to:
• Collaborate with diverse members of the design team to realise
interdisciplinary design solutions based on systems engineering
principles that balance and integrate their own disciplinary
technical requirements with those of the team to the satisfaction
of the project requirements.
• Define, monitor and evaluate their project team’s values (KPIs)
in a professional manner.
• Evaluate the design models and reports from previous course
cohorts to identify the challenges to balancing the project and
disciplinary requirements in a complex building project.
• Strategise, track and update a design management scheme (DMS)
to support team coordination and collaboration based on analysis of
the project requirements.
• Develop, maintain and evaluate a digital benchmark building
model (BBM) to assess design proposals throughout the project
against analysis of the project requirements
• Communicate and investigate the building design and analysis
using models, drawings, reports, diagrams, dashboards and
presentations to internal and or external assessors to a
professional level.
• Guide the building design team with technical subject reports
based on disciplinary analysis to provide the scientific foundation
for the 'higher level' guidance in the client report.
• Actively support alternative interdisciplinary design solution
options to support an integrated design process that provides
meaningful choices to the client and design team.
• Model and analyse digital OpenBIM building models using
computational design and disciplinary analysis tools to provide
realtime guidance to the whole team throughout the design
process.
• Make and justify your design decisions based on the project
requirements, team needs and reflection on the client, disciplinary
expert and peer feedback to improve the design throughout the
design process.
content:
The course aims to teach you to balance your developing
disciplinary expertise and responsibilities to the needs of the
design team, client and project in a ‘real’ collaborative design
process. The course follows an integrated building design process
covering the following 4 stages:
A) Analyse client and project needs in a 'real' project and
develop strategies to address these in one of seven roles;
Architect, Structures, MEP, Geotech, Fire, PM/ICT or Material/LCA.
B) Design and analyse different options by defining evaluate
different design tactics to satisfy your team’s design strategies
in BIM to guide the client.
C) Collaborate to integrate the building systems of different
disciplines to satisfy technical and design requirements.
D) Detail and communicate a final design to a variety of
stakeholders in technical reports and a presentation including VR
based on your reflection of the feedback received in the previous
parts of the course.

course_name: Structural design of precast concrete buildings
general_course_objectives:
The main objective is for the students to be able to carry out a
structural design of a multi-storey building consisting of mainly
precast concrete elements.
learning_objectives:
A student who has met the objectives of the course will be able to:
• Explain the structural system of a multi-storey precast
concrete building
• Explain how requirements and non-structural elements influence
the structural system
• Determine and calculate the relevant load actions on a
building
• Describe the load path through a building
• Analyze a precast concrete building subjected to vertical loads
and design a load carrying system
• Analyze the stability of a precast concrete building subjected
to horizontal loads and design a bracing system
• Evaluate individual elements in service state and ultimate
limit state
• Apply relevant joints in connections between precast concrete
elements
content:
The course mainly consists of lectures and project work in groups
with sub-assignments. In the project group, the students design a
multi-storey precast concrete building based on the topics from the
lectures and most often in accordance with the European standards.
Some of the methods learned are also applicable for buildings of
other materials.
The students are graded based on the assessment of one or two
reports about topics from the project work. The students will get
formative feedback during the course, e.g. via peer assessment.
Some of the topics are: Load combinations, design of horizontal and
vertical members, stabilizing walls, the rigid floor method,
structural joints etc.

general_course_objectives:
The future is uncertain. Architectural engineering with uncertainty
requires agile thinking, in order to model, adapt and redesign
building systems and products fast. The course aims to provide
‘future tools’ to enable participants to design ‘in the future’.
The focus of the course is to support participants to model, design
and analyse building systems, fast for a clearly defined future
scenario.
learning_objectives:
A student who has met the objectives of the course will be able to:
• Identify a building system or product that has or could address
a current or emerging disciplinary problem in the architecture,
engineering and construction industry.
• Identify the ‘phenotypic’ features of a building system or
product.
• Reverse engineer the pseudo biological developmental stages of
the system based on the identified features to transform the
building system or product into an ‘Agile Prototype' (AP).
• Model and traverse a phylogenetic tree of the features of AP to
identify new solutions.
• Apply computational modelling techniques to model the evolution
of the AP.
• Extrapolate the future features of the AP based on its
evolution.
• Reflect on the APs genetic future trajectory.
• Define the three horizons of a future scenario and explore the
future of the AP.
• Adapt the AP to the three horizons of the future scenario.
• Define an agile roadmap for the AP to solve the identified
problem.
• Evaluate their proposed AP.
• Reflect on the process of developing the AP and communicate
this for current and future students.
content:
In the course, students use these tools to extend their view of the
present towards Elise Boulding’s idea of a 200 year present.
Working in groups, they develop an ‘Agile Prototype’ of a building
system or product that includes 100 years of the building system or
products past, as well as 100 years of its future.
The Agile Prototyping methodology used in the course synthesises
agile design processes, computational design, biomimetics and
future forecasting to provide participants with a future focused
design, analysis and modelling skills in architectural engineering.
Agile Prototyping applies a biological science lens to the built
environment to identify the ‘genes’ of the built environment. This
will enable future architectural engineers to hack the pseudo
genetic code of our built environment. To enable the fast
(re)design and analysis of our built environment.
Agile Prototyping has four stages: A1 #FORECAST FUTURES: Define 3
future scenarios near, medium and far using the 3 Horizons
Framework and Science Fiction Prototyping. Overarching concept for
this assignment is the future concept of Forecasting with the
purpose of guiding innovation by creating a target that you can use
to test your agile prototypes later in the course.
A2 #WHATS NEEDED?
Overarching concept for this assignment is the future concept of
Backcasting with the purpose of supporting codesign of solutions.
The concepts are based in traditional in requirements engineering
but they extended so that they can used in meta disciplinary
analysis of the selected building system. This stage intorduces the
design science research methodology (DSRM) so that students define
their solution objectives, based on then problem identification in
the previous stage.
(3) #DISCOVER GENES: Focus on the modelling of the agile Prototype
using biodigital prototyping methods. Reverse engineer the features
(genes) and pseudo developmental stages of the agile prototype
(building system or product). Overarching concept for this
assignment is the future concept of Pastcasting with the purpose of
revealing biases. This applies the concepts of biological
development to inform the development of our agile biodigtal
prototype. This follows the design and development and
demonstration stages of DSRM.
(4) #COMPUTE VECTORS: Model the history (evolution) of the
prototype and use this to determine the prototype’s current future
trajectory. This happens by applying the biological concept of
evolutionary development to the
‘Overarching concept for this assignment is the future concept of
recasting with the purpose of evoking imagination and in our case
imagining the future trajectory of building system features based
on their current ‘genes’ identified in assignment 2 and future
needs. This follows the evaluate and communicate steps of the DSRM.

course_name: Advanced Digital Technologies in Construction Projects
general_course_objectives:
This course focuses on the use of remote sensing and data
processing techniques in construction projects and the development
of digital building models, as carriers of project information for
data extraction, exchange, and communication in applications
ranging from automated progress reporting to automation and
robotics in construction.
learning_objectives:
A student who has met the objectives of the course will be able to:
• identify sensors to measure parameters related to construction
sites
• evaluate the current and the different levels of automation and
robotics in construction
• analyze and assess potentials and barriers in implementing
remote sensing in building information modeling (BIM) and virtual
design in construction (VDC)
• independently find relevant and supplementary information for
remote sensing techniques
• develop a measurement plan using remote sensing for
construction applications
• interpret and analyze captured data
• create as-built 3D models from point cloud data
• apply and explore remote sensing techniques for observing
construction site progress
content:
This course will focus on advances in digital technologies in
construction. The themes to be covered are development, instrument
configuration, and application of various remote sensing
technologies as radio frequency identification, global navigation
satellite system; 3D point cloud data capturing from ground and
airborne instruments such as laser scanning, light detection and
ranging, unmanned aerial vehicles, and photo-and videogrammetry.
After the data collection the students will use methods in signal
processing and data analysis such as filtering, noise reduction,
and feature extraction for topic-relevant applications or use
cases. These include construction site progress monitoring with
real-time resource location sensing and tracking; as-built modeling
from range point-clouds; right-time proactive construction safety,
health, and wellbeing; automated or human-machine guidance and
interaction; general automation and robotics applications in
construction. Theoretical aspects of the harsh work environment and
the complex and dynamic nature of construction site
characteristics, often relevant to the success or failure of remote
sensing, will also be covered.
Course activities in and outside the laboratory will explore three
major areas that create challenges for embedding advanced
technologies in construction projects:
• Complexity, with a particular focus on the relationship of
technical vs. organizational complexity.
• Investment, with a focus on identifying and mitigating key risks
from a business and process point of view.
• Human acceptance, addressing the social and organizational
intricacies caused by automation, personal rights, and
intra-organizational factors.

general_course_objectives:
The aim of the course is to provide an introductory knowledge of
building technology and architecture for architectural engineers.
Once you have followed the course, you will be able to record and
analyze simpler buildings, explain their architectural concepts and
relationships to the development of the history of architecture and
technology. You will be able to explain the constructive design and
construction engineering of simpler buildings, including explaining
their static and climate engineering modes of operation.
learning_objectives:
A student who has met the objectives of the course will be able to:
• Explain the function and expression of buildings
• Explain the systems of buildings and how they work
• Analyze buildings based on building registration
• Explain static principles for simpler buildings and present
them graphically
• Explain the design of the thermal envelope and present it
graphically
• Explain architectural concepts and represent them
graphically
• Explain important architectural trends, name the most important
architectural works and architects from the 20th century
• Reflect on own work and own learning
content:
The course introduces basic knowledge of construction technology
and architecture through lectures, excursions and exercises.
The teaching includes sketching- and note techniques, building
registration, building analysis with a focus on architecture,
construction, thermal envelope, materials and sustainability. An
understanding of the systems of buildings as well as the
architectural concepts of buildings is built up, and features of
the historical prerequisites of building technology and
architecture are also reviewed.
The course practises individual work, group work, presentationas
well as report writing and presentation according to recognized
formats.
The course includes knowledge obtained in the other 1st-semester
courses.

general_course_objectives:
The course introduces practice-oriented design methods for
architectural engineers and gives you the opportunity to test your
acquired knowledge by designing (proposing, optimizing and
documenting) a smaller, wood-based building.
When you have followed the course, you can participate in an
elementary building design process and - on the basis of a defined
problem - develop relevant solutions, select the best solutions and
communicate the results using drawings, models, presentations and
reports.
learning_objectives:
A student who has met the objectives of the course will be able to:
• Design a single building through a recognized design process
(Double Diamond, first diamond)
• Design constructions, thermal envelope and technical systems
(heating and ventilation) in smaller buildings.
• Suggest and test alternative solutions
• Apply various visual tools in the design process, including
analog and digital sketching and physical model building
• Include references from real architectural and engineering
projects in the work
• Create relevant project communication through sketches,
drawings and models
• Present project results orally and written
• Create project results in groups
content:
Design theory (Double Diamond, first diamond). Proposal making,
alternative solutions, evaluation, optimization. Find/use
architectural and engineering references. Projecting. Sketching,
drawing, model building. Presentation technique, report writing.

general_course_objectives:
The course gives you an introduction to the connection between
architecture, daylight and acoustics through knowledge of the
theory of phenomenology within architecture, the engineering
processing of the phenomena of daylight and acoustics (quality and
quantity) as well as the good examples in reality.
When you have followed the course, you will be able to engage in
dialogue with users and architects about light quality and acoustic
quality in construction; with simple methods experience, measure,
model and calculate the most important lighting and acoustic
properties for daylight distribution and reverberation time and
compare and evaluate the results achieved.
learning_objectives:
A student who has met the objectives of the course will be able to:
• Explain the content of the phenomenology theory in relation to
architecture
• Explain the basic concepts and most important parameters within
daylighting and acoustics (hereinafter referred to as "indoor
climate") in rooms
• Describe indoor climate experiences in rooms based on
observations
• Carry out simple measurements of important parameters for the
quality and quantity of indoor climate in rooms
• Determine daylight conditions and reverberation time in rooms
using physical and digital models and calculation.
• Evaluate and discuss consistency and deviation between
experienced, measured and calculated indoor climate results
• Design and place light openings, acoustic absorbers and
reflectors in rooms to optimize the indoor climate
• Give an account of selected, relevant reference works with
particularly good indoor climate properties within the history of
architecture
• Reflect on own work and own learning
content:
Introduction to the phenomenology theory of architecture. The
relationship between light and sound as experienced, measured and
calculated/modelled phenomena. Basic daylight engineering and
acoustic concepts. Measurement of light and sound. Knowledge of
daylight and modelling/calculation of quantity and quality of
daylight in buildings. Knowledge of room acoustics and
modeling/calculation of reverberation time. Knowledge of
sound-absorbing materials and calculation of necessary absorbers to
achieve appropriate acoustics in rooms with simple geometry.
Analytical problem solving, group work, communication (report
writing and presentation), note-taking technique, reflection on own
learning and the group's results.

course_name: Architectural Engineering Design Project 2, indoor climatic design
general_course_objectives:
The course gives you the opportunity to test your knowledge gained
in the 1-2nd semester by developing the design of a complex
building which has special daylighting and acoustic needs, e.g. a
cultural center with an exhibition space and a concert hall.
When you have followed the course, you can participate in an
integrated building design process and - on the basis of ao open
problem, develop relevant solutions, select the best solutions and
communicate the results using drawings, modelling, presentations
and reports.
The course develops design and project skills, which have been
acquired in course 41942.
learning_objectives:
A student who has met the objectives of the course will be able to:
• Design an advanced building with indoor climate technology with
a focus on light and acoustics through a planned design
process
• Analyze problems and context for an actual indoor-climatic
oriented design project
• Propose and test alternative solutions
• Select significant parameters for optimization of
solutions
• Use various (subject-)relevant tools in the design process,
including analogue and digital sketching, (digital-) modeling and
BIM
• Incorporate and process references from real architectural and
engineering projects in the work
• Create effective project communication orally, graphically and
in writing
• Create project results in groups with self-defined division of
labor
content:
Integrated Design with a particular focus on the interaction of
daylight and acoustics with an architectural, functional and
durable building concept.
Design Theory (Double Diamond). Proposals, alternative solutions,
evaluation, optimization, planning. Communication of results
through drawings, physical/BIM models, presentations and reports.
Documentation of design decisions within daylighting and acoustics.
Planning a study trip to a local or european destination. Project
planning and group work with individual responsibility. Reflection
on own learning and the group's results (process report).

general_course_objectives:
The course gives you an overview of different structural design
principles and the corresponding static calculations.
When you have completed the course, you will have gained an
understanding of the force distribution in specific types of
structures, such as beams, columns, frames, trusses, cables,
arches, and cupolas, when they are subjected to ordinary loads. You
can also check the capacity of particular load-carrying and
stabilising structural elements. Furthermore, you will be able to
design a larger construction with a holistic approach accounting
for the material consumption and the function.
learning_objectives:
A student who has met the objectives of the course will be able to:
• Explain the structural design principles of modern
architecture
• Describe the loads and load combinations used in building
design in Denmark
• Explain the behaviour and requirements of more complex building
systems
• Analyze buildings with different typologies
• Create a construction with reduced material consumption
• Calculate the capacity of the load carrying structure of
complex builidings
• Explain the relation between materials and statics
• Assess a structural design with a holistic approach, including
aesthetics, function, material choice, buildability, etc.
content:
Introduction to different structural types and their static
behaviour.
The course content includes calculation principles, structural
shaping, choice of materials and more aestetic considerations when
designing a larger construction.
The students work with the course topics via several exercises
where they:
- Calculate load carrying capacity of components and joined
structures of specific materials.
- Learn how vertical and horizontal loads are transmitted to the
foundation via the load-carrying and stabilising system.
- Design their own building shapes and choose materials from
demands to structural size and material consumption.
The course includes time for a mid-way peer assessment, which is
not graded, and purely to increase the level of deep learning.

course_name: Architectural Engineering Design Project 3, Structural Design
general_course_objectives:
The course provides you with the opportunity to apply the knowledge
gained in the 1st-3rd semesters by working on the design of a
sustainably designed complex building, which presents specific
structural challenges such as a high-rise building or a structure
with large spans.
Upon completion of the course, you will be able to actively
participate in an integrated building design process. You will be
equipped to identify and develop relevant solutions based on a
given problem, select the best solutions, and effectively
communicate the results through drawings, models, presentations,
and reports.
This course builds upon the design and project skills acquired in
course 41945, while incorporating design processes from course
41941 with a specific focus on structural aspects.
learning_objectives:
A student who has met the objectives of the course will be able to:
• Design a structural advanced building through a planned design
process
• Analyze problems and context for an actual structural-oriented
design project
• Propose and test alternative solutions
• Select significant parameters for optimization
• Use various (subject-)relevant tools in the design process,
including analogue/digital sketching, (digital-) modeling and
BIM
• Incorporate and process references from real architectural and
engineering projects in the work
• Create effective project communication orally, graphically and
in writing
• Create project results in groups with self-defined division of
labor
• Reflect on own learning, the group's processes and results
in the project work
content:
Integrated Design with a particular emphasis on the interaction of
structures within an architectural, functional, and sustainable
building concept.
Design Theory (Double Diamond): Proposing, exploring alternatives,
evaluating, optimizing, and planning. Communicating results through
drawings, physical/BIM models, presentations, and reports. Project
planning and group work with individual responsibilities.
Reflecting on personal learning (notebook) and the group's
outcomes (process report)

general_course_objectives:
The course gives you the opportunity to plan the renovation and
transformation of existing buildings in order to extend the life of
buildings and thus strengthen sustainable development.
Once you have followed the course, you can assess the condition of
existing buildings in order to repair damage and improve usability.
learning_objectives:
A student who has met the objectives of the course will be able to:
• Describe the engineer's role in building renovation
• Assess and outline options for conversion and transformation of
buildings for other uses
• Combine solutions with sustainability considerations, including
LCA/LCC calculations in the assessment of different renovation and
transformation options
• Analyze the condition of an existing building in terms of
damage and potentials
• Explain typical Danish building structures from different eras
as well as their strengths and weaknesses
• Select relevant renovation methodology in different types of
renovation tasks
• Produce solutions for renovating typical building parts in the
building envelope
• Address current issues regarding hazardous substances in
existing buildings such as PCBs, mercury, lead, mould
etc.
content:
The course will present various typical Danish building traditions
of different eras, including the strengths and weaknesses that
characterize these.
The student will be introduced to the civil engineer's
traditional contribution to transformation and renovation
processes, e.g. through knowledge of applied materials and
structures. This is to be able to analyze an existing building,
both in terms of typical damage and strengths and thus potentials
for conversion and transformation. This will also include issues
regarding different types of hazardous substances that have been
used over time.
Based on this, various options for renovation are analysed, both
overall and at building component level.
When assessing opportunities for renovation and transformation, the
focus will be on the optimal use of resources; key topics will
therefore be:
- Service life and lifetime extension, not only technically but
also functionally and aesthetically
- Reuse of elements in construction
- Contribution to CO2 reduction and Life Cycle Assessment
(LCA)/Life Cycle Costing (LCC) calculations
- Energy savings
- Residual carrying capacity

course_name: Architectural Engineering Design Project 4, Building transformation design
general_course_objectives:
The course gives you the opportunity to test your acquired
knowledge and skills on the education and more specifically from
course 41947 by carrying out a sustainability-oriented building
transformation project.
The project is based on a real case - an existing building that has
served its purpose. Through the analysis, evaluation and proposal
of the project work, it is documented that the building has the
potential to be used for a new purpose in the future and thus
fulfill this new purpose with a smaller climate footprint as a
result than a new building would entail.
When you have followed the course, you as an architectural engineer
can participate in an integrated building design process within
sustainable building transformation - and thus contribute to
creating sustainable solutions in relation to usability, durability
and beauty within the built environment.
learning_objectives:
A student who has met the objectives of the course will be able to:
• Carry out an integrated and interdisciplinary design process,
in which the individual student contributes to project solutions
with their own specialization within e.g. construction, energy or
indoor climate.
• Propose and document a sustainable building transformation
based on a real case
• Select, register and collect relevant building data from a real
building
• Evaluate a building's transformation potential in relation
to form, condition, function, cultural value and environmental
impact
• Create sustainable, optimized design solutions with the focus
on maintaining and expanding existing building values
• Select and use optimal data and tools in the design
process
• Create project results in groups and in interaction with
external partners
• Create effective and in-depth project communication to various
stakeholders
content:
Practice integrated design and interdisciplinary design based on
the phase model within construction cf. Danske Ark's and
FRI's service description. Building registration,
conceptualisation, proposal, alternative solutions, optimization of
function, architectural expression, use of materials, energy
consumption and indoor climate quality, planning, receiving and
giving feedback, communication of results through physical/BIM
models, prototypes, presentations, video formats and reports.
Documentation of design decisions within construction, material
selection, energy, indoor climate and LCA. Project planning, group
work with individual responsibilities and cooperation with external
parties.

general_course_objectives:
The course provides a fundamental understanding of the mechanical
properties of wood such as strength, stiffness, load duration and
moisture, and how the material wood is used as basic beam and
column elements for structural design. The course also covers basic
connection design using dowel type fasteners such as nails, dowels
and bolts.
learning_objectives:
A student who has met the objectives of the course will be able to:
• Explain how the characteristics of the material wood effect its
use as a construction material
• Define relevant material properties of wood for use in
structural design.
• Evaluate different timber products and their application in
basic structural systems.
• Use relevant standards and literature in design of basic wood
structures.
• Define and handle duration dependent loads on wood
structures.
• Assess the tensile, compressive, shear and flexural strength of
straight wood-based elements.
• Evaluate the instantaneous and permanent deformations of
straight wood-based elements.
• Evaluate the impact of local instability (buckling and lateral
torsional buckling) on the strength of timber elements.
• Calculate the dowel effect of nails, bolts, and dowels and
design connections in timber structures composed of multiple
fasteners.
content:
The course cover mechanical properties of wood and wood-based
products, statical calculation models of straight timber members
/beams and columns) in the Ultimate (ULS) and Serviceability Limit
States (SLS), duration dependent loads on wood structures,
influence of moisture on design of timber structures, construction
wood-based elements (structural timber, glued laminated timber, and
other Engineered Wood Products (EWP)), fasteners and joint design
using dowels, bolts and nails, as well as local instability
problems, i.e., flexural and lateral torsional buckling. The course
consists of lectures and solving assignments throughout the course.

general_course_objectives:
1. To give the students basic knowledge of static calculations of
timber structures, including the influence of anisotropy and
natural growth defects of wood.
2. Be able to design the static system of long-span timber
buildings, based on beams-columns structural elements.
3. To build knowledge and skills in the design of basic structural
elements and connections that are related to practical use.
4. Students acquire knowledge and skills in planning and
maintaining structures with emphasis on long-span timber
constructions.
learning_objectives:
A student who has met the objectives of the course will be able to:
• Describe the assumptions behind the calculation methods used in
Eurocode 5, Design of timber Structures.
• Evaluate the application of different wood-based construction
elements.
• Make simple, qualitative assessments concerning choice of
structural systems and more detailed calculations of typical
constructions in practice.
• Analyze simple timber structures from a practical perspective
and determine appropriate structural elements of long-span timber
buildings.
• Design beams, columns and built-up elements in timber
constructions based on Eurocode 5.
• Design mechanical fasteners and simple connections in timber
constructions based on Eurocode 5.
• Determine deformations in structural elements and simple timber
structures.
• Evaluate the fire resistance of simple timber elements in
accordance with Eurocode 5.
• Describe different construction methods and propose the most
relevant method for long-span timber structures.
• Communicate and argue for solutions both in writing and
orally.
• Conduct and present calculations in a structured and readable
form.
content:
The course consists of lectures, seminars and preparation of a
project assignment.
1. Mechanical properties of wood including strength, deformation
and moisture conditions, rot, waterproofing and fire conditions.
2. Setting up the statical calculation models, including relevant
load combinations.
3. Construction elements based on wood: structural timber,
laminated wood, plywood, chipboard and fiberboard
4. Fasteners and joints: Glue, Dowels, Bolts, Nails, Screws and
metal plates.
5. Calculation of multiple fasteners connections.
6. Calculation of strength and deformation of structural elements
and structures of timber (ULS), including massive and composite
beams and columns and stressed skin elements.
7. Stability problems, including folding of flanges and webs, and
lateral torsional buckling.
8. Calculations in the serviceability limit state (SLS).
9. Stiffening elements of wood based materials.
10. Cross-laminated Timber (CLT)
11. Fire resistance of wood
12. Special construction methods for timber structures

general_course_objectives:
The course provides an introduction to the calculation and design
of load-bearing structures. It covers determination of reactions,
section forces and beam deformations under various loads and
boundary conditions.
Additionally, the course includes an introduction to stresses,
strains, and strengths of materials. It also familiarizes students
with simple calculation methods and numerical tools for designing
and optimizing structures. Topics covered include beams, columns,
bars, frames, and trusses, enabling students to analyze and design
simple, statically determined structures. The course forms the
primary foundation for subsequent structural engineering courses.
learning_objectives:
A student who has met the objectives of the course will be able to:
• Describe loading with forces and moments
• Establish equations of equilibrium and determine reactions
• Determine section forces in statically determinate beam
structures
• Determine member forces in statically determinate truss
structures
• Use the principle of virtual work for the determination of
reactions and deformations in truss- and beam structures
• Use simple, numerical programs to determine reactions, section
forces and deformations
• Determine moment of inertia for simple cross sections
• Determine normal stresses in trusses, beams, columns and
frames
• Establish equations of equilibrium and determine the load
carrying capacity of columns
content:
- Forces and moments
- Equilibrium
- Section forces
- Normal stresses and strains
- Deformations
- Trusses
- Beams
- Columns
- Frames
Examples of structural analysis with simple, numerical programs are
demonstrated or used as a possible control of the results in the
exercises

general_course_objectives:
The objective of the course is to develop the students basic
structural understanding which will allow them to perform an
analysis of the state of stress in simple structures.
learning_objectives:
A student who has met the objectives of the course will be able to:
• Determine sectional forces og deformations for statically
indeterminate beams by the force method
• Determine cross sectional constants for general cross
sections
• Determine principal moments of inertia for general cross
sections
• Determine normal stress distribution for beams in bending
• Determine shear stress distribution for beams in bending
• Determine shear stress distribution for beams in torsion
• Analyse special states of stress and strain
• Decide if a state of stress is critical to a given
material
content:
- Section forces in statically indeterminate beam structures
- Normal stresses in beams in bending
- Shear stresses in beams in bending and in torsion
- Special states of strain and stress
- Principal stresses and Mohr's circle
- Stress invariants
- Mechanical properties of materials
- Simple failure conditions

course_name: Structural engineering 3: Frame and Plate Structures
general_course_objectives:
To teach the participants modelling and analysis of structures made
of frames and plates, based on linear, stability and plastic
analysis, respectively.
learning_objectives:
A student who has met the objectives of the course will be able to:
• Apply the deformation method to determine deformations,
reaction forces and section forces for simple frame
structures.
• Perform a stability analysis for simple frame structures and
determine the buckling load.
• Determine the critical load for plastic collapse of simple
frame structures by upper limit methods.
• Determine the critical load for plastic collapse of simple
frame structures by lower limit methods.
• Perform manual calculations of plates
• Calculate the stability of plates
• Perform hand calculations of load carrying capacity in plate
bending plasticity based on the yield line method
• Perform simple manual calculations of thinwalled
beams
content:
The deformation method for two-dimensional elastic frames including
stability. Plastic analysis of frame structures using lower and
upper bound methods.
Basic plate theory including moments, shear forces, corner forces
and virtual work.
Stability analysis of plates.
Calculation of load carrying capacity in plate bending plasticity
based on the yield line method. Introductory theory for thinwalled
beams.

general_course_objectives:
To make the student capable of designing structural elements in
simple concrete structures.
learning_objectives:
A student who has met the objectives of the course will be able to:
• Describe the characteristics of a reinforced concrete structure
and explain the principles in design of simple structural elements
made of reinforced concrete
• Describe the safety concept to apply in design of reinforced
concrete structures based on Eurocode 2
• Perform calculations of load carrying capacity in the ultimate
limit state of simple structural elements
• Analyze structural elements, such as beam, columns, and plates,
and estimate failure modes and associated load carrying
capacity
• Apply the upper and lower bound theorems of limit analysis to
simple reinforced concrete structures and evaluate their
applicability to a given problem
• Design structural elements to meet requirements in the
serviceability limit state and ultimate limit state according to
Eurocode 2 provisions
• Describe the numerical method and apply numerical tool for
analysis of reinforced concrete cross sections with biaxial
bending
• Describe the numerical method and apply numerical tool for
yield line analysis of two-way spanning reinforced concrete
slabs
content:
The behavior of reinforced concrete
Safety concept according to Eurocode
Capacity calculation in the Ultimate Limit State for beams, slabs,
and columns
Determination of crack widths and deflections of beams in the
Serviceability Limit State
Design of reinforced concrete structural elements (beams, slabs,
and columns)
Introduction to numerical methods for stress analysis in arbitrary
cross sections and for analysis of collapse mechanisms in slabs
Use of application-ready Matlab-based programs for cross-section
analysis and slab analysis

general_course_objectives:
To make it possible for the students to analyse and design
elementary structural members and connections in steel structures.
learning_objectives:
A student who has met the objectives of the course will be able to:
• Explain the material and mechanical properties which form the
basis for models and analysis.
• Explain the connection of plates by welding.
• Explain the connection of plates by bolting.
• Make a cross-sectional analysis of elements in steel
structures.
• Perform stability analysis of beams and columns.
• Take into account local buckling of plate parts in beams and
columns.
• Perform analysis and calculation of elementary bolted and
welded joints.
• Explain the elastic and plastic analysis of steel
structures.
content:
Material and mechanical properties in steel structures. Connection
of plates by welding and bolting. Cross-sectional analysis of
elements in steel structures. Stability analysis of beams and
columns. Local buckling of plate parts in beams and columns.
Analysis and calculation of elementary bolted and welded joints.
Elastic and plastic analysis of steel structures.

course_name: Computational Structural Modelling 1: The Finite Element Method
general_course_objectives:
The Finite Element Method (FEM) is a widely used tool among Civil
Engineers (and Engineers in general) due to its generality and
flexibility in a large number of engineering problems. Although
most practitioners use commercial programs, an understanding of the
underlying theory is a necessity for performing reasonable,
realistic and reliable analyzes using FEM.
This course focuses on the fundamentals behind the method and
provides the theoretical basis for further studies, as well as the
use of FEM as a design tool. The course is oriented towards
constructions and the structural mechanics area.
learning_objectives:
A student who has met the objectives of the course will be able to:
• Establish the Finite Element Method equations directly for bar
and beams.
• Establish the Finite Element Method equations for bars, beams,
discs, plates and shells based on the principle of virtual
work.
• Understand, use and derive interpolations for approximation of
field variables.
• Understand and apply the isoparametric method for the
development of elements.
• Understand different structural element types.
• Apply and evaluate the results obtained using different
structural element types.
• Perform and assess stability analysis of structures.
• Apply a commercial FEM program and perform critical assessment
of the results
• Program and modify linear Finite Element programs.
content:
Introduction to the finite element method for structural design
purposes. Emphasis is placed on the systematic development of the
Finite Element Method based on the principle of virtual work. The
course is structured around lectures and exercises covering both
analytical approach, programming the Finite Element Method and the
use of a commercial software.

general_course_objectives:
The course builds on the basic understanding of design of
wood-based element and connections, by introducing the complete
design of a larger timber structure with long spans. The design
work includes vertical and horizontal load distribution, design of
all primary and secondary structural elements, design of all
connections and verification of bracing and stability.
learning_objectives:
A student who has met the objectives of the course will be able to:
• Evaluate the application of different wood-based construction
elements.
• Conduct simple, qualitative assessments concerning choice of
structural systems and more detailed calculations of typical
constructions in practice.
• Analyze simple timber structures from a practical perspective
and determine appropriate structural elements of large timber
structures.
• Calculate beams, columns and built-up elements that are
appropriate for large timber structures.
• Calculate mechanical fasteners and simple connections in timber
constructions that ensures vertical and horizontal load
distribution.
• Determine deformations in structural elements for large timber
structures.
• Evaluate the fire resistance of simple timber elements and
apply fire protection systems in accordance with relevant
standards.
• Describe different construction methods and propose the most
relevant method for large timber structures.
• Communicate and argue for solutions both in writing and
orally.
content:
The course covers mechanical properties of wood including strength,
deformations, moisture conditions and fire conditions. Setting up
statical calculation models, including relevant load combinations.
Construction elements based on wood: structural timber, laminated
wood, plywood, chipboard and fiberboard. Fasteners and joints:
Dowels, Bolts, Nails, Screws and metal plates. Calculation of
multiple fasteners connections. Calculation of strength and
deformation of structural elements and timber structures. Stability
problems and lateral torsional buckling. Calculations in the
serviceability limit state (SLS). Stiffening elements of wood based
materials. Cross-laminated Timber (CLT). Fire resistance of wood.
Special construction methods for timber structures. The course
consists of lectures, seminars and preparation of a project
assignment covering the full design of a large timber structure.

course_name: Computational Structural Modelling 2: Non-linear Finite Element Method
general_course_objectives:
The scope is to introduce finite element models for non-linear FEM
problems within structural mechanics, including geometric
non-linearity, dynamic behaviour and ideal plastic optimization of
collaps load.
learning_objectives:
A student who has met the objectives of the course will be able to:
• Establish non-linear models for simple truss systems.
• Understand and apply non-linear solution methods.
• Understand and apply relevant error measures for iteration
control.
• Establish the Finite Element Method equations for geometrical
non-linear trusses.
• Establish the Finite Element Method equations for geometrical
non-linear shells.
• Establish the Finite Element Method equations for dynamic
systems with damping.
• Understand and apply solution methods for dynamic
problems.
• Perform a critical evaluation of quality of dynamic calculation
results.
• Establish the Finite Element Method equations for ideal plastic
optimization of collaps load.
• Understand and apply solution methods for optimization of
collaps load.
• Programme and modify non-linear FEM-programs.
content:
Introduction to the fundamental theoretical basis for the
formulation of geometrical non-linear and dynamic behaviour, as
well as optimization of collaps load, and description of the
corresponding FEM formulation. Presentation of classic solution
strategies and their numerical implementation. The course is
structured around lectures and exercises covering both analytical
approach, further development of supplied Matlab-code, independent
Matlab programming and the use of a commercial program.

learning_objectives:
A student who has met the objectives of the course will be able to:
• Understand plasticity in concrete and reinforced concrete
• Explain the requirements for plasticity in reinforced
concrete.
• Understand the behavior of concrete structures with and without
reinforcement. Understand and recognize the various failure modes
and their ductility
• Perform lower bound analyses of concrete and reinforced
concrete structures
• Understand and use plasticicty methods such as: The Stringer
method; Strut and Tie modeling; Homogeneous stress fields;
Yieldline method for plane stress and plane strain problems
• Perform upper bound analyses of concrete and reinforced
concrete structures
• Perform reinforcement design for structural elements in
concrete based on plasticity methods.
• Perform detailing of reinforcement layout in structural
elements of concrete based on plasticity analysis.
• Perform calculations for pre-tensioned and post-tensioned
concrete structures in short term response.
• Perform calculations for pre-tensioned and post-tensioned
concrete structures in long term response.
• Calculate strain and stresses for prestressed concrete
structures
• Calculate deformations for prestressed concrete
structures
content:
• Plasticity and limit analysis of concrete and reinforced
concrete. Design and strength assessment by use of lower and upper
bound methods. Practical application to disks, plates, beams and
general plane stress and plane strain problems.
• Prestressed concrete structures with short and long term effects.

general_course_objectives:
The course aims at giving the participants a detailed knowledge of
analysis and design of steel structures, enabling them to deal with
more advanced steel structures.
learning_objectives:
A student who has met the objectives of the course will be able to:
• Explain the assumptions that form the basis for advanced models
and analysis.
• Carry out qualitative evaluations as well as detailed analysis
of steel structures.
• Carry out analysis and design of more advanced steel structures
from practice.
• Carry out analysis and design of member joints with bolted and
welded connections.
• Carry out analysis and design of plate girders, including
determination of post-critical capacity.
• Carry out analysis and design of steel columns, including
built-up columns.
• Carry out analysis and design of thin-walled structures.
• Carry out analysis and design of composite structures
concrete/steel.
• Determine the fatigue life of steel structures.
content:
Member joints using bolting and welding. Plate girders: Stiffened
girders. Plastic moment capacity. Post-critical moment capacity and
stiffened panels. Composite girders concrete/steel. Built-up
columns. Special, more complicated structural elements and
connections: End-plate connections. Beam-to-columm connections.
Steel structures subject to fatigue. Fracture mechanics
determination of fatigue life.

general_course_objectives:
The course’s intention is to enhance the engineering student’s
ability to design structures against earthquakes and wind, by
progressively examining the causes of earthquakes and the nature of
atmospheric wind, the principles behind the dynamic analysis of
seismic and wind loading of structures, lessons learned from the
past and structural repair, retrofit and control.
learning_objectives:
A student who has met the objectives of the course will be able to:
• Understand earthquake generating mechanisms
• Describe the natural wind boundary layer and the significance
of turbulence
• Calculate modal mass and stiffness of a structure
• Perform a seismic response spectrum analysis of structure
• Perform a dynamic linear time-history analysis
• Calculation of peak response of a high-rise building to wind
loading
• Probabilistic analysis of wind load process and other
effects
• Understand lessons learnt from past earthquakes and storms
• Gain awareness of structural repair and retrofit
principles
• Describe the most relevant structural control strategies
• Follow Eurocodes 1 and 8
content:
-Plate tectonics and seismic wave types
-The wind velocity profile and turbulence intensity
-The concept of wind and response spectra, accelerograms and
pressure time-histories
-Dynamic seismic and wind analysis methods and principles behind
seismic “Force-based” design
-Introduction to Eurocodes 1 & 8 and the concept of structural
ductility
-Seismic “displacement-based design”
-Design principles based on experience
-Structural failure mechanisms and fatigue
-Structural repair, retrofit and control
-Static and dynamic response calculation to wind
-Probabilistic analysis

general_course_objectives:
The course’s intention is to enhance the engineering student’s
ability to design bridge structures, including conceptual design,
qualified selection of statical systems, global and local
structural analysis, structural dimensioning at different detailing
levels. Particular emphasis on cable-supported bridges. Various
bridge types are presented, followed by a detailed examination of
the bridge's constituent components, their structual function
and mutual structural interaction. Specialist issues, such as
dynamic loading and construction engineering (erection methods) are
introduced.
learning_objectives:
A student who has met the objectives of the course will be able to:
• Display a historical overview of bridge types
• Describe the structrural behaviour of various types of
bridges
• Choose an optimal bridge configuration for a particular span
and particular foundation condition
• Understand the differences between different cable-supported
bridges, such as suspension bridges and cable-stayed bridges
• Examine the various components of a bridge
• Describe the load paths for different bridges
• Have knowledge of basic aerodynamic phenomena for longer-span
bridges
• Perform conceptual design, preliminary design and analysis of
various types of bridges, such as continuous beam bridges,
cable-stayed bridges and suspension bridges.
• Perform detailed analysis and design of bridge components in
prestressed concrete, structural steel and steel-concrete composite
members
• Analyse the effects of moving trafic loads
• Discuss construction techniques
content:
-Bridge history and design assumptions
-Selection of bridge spans, design considerations
-Study of suspension and cable-stayed bridges with long spans
-Investigate the various components of a bridge
-Bridge dynamics
-Special bridges, for example. pedestrian bridges
-Bridge construction techniques

general_course_objectives:
This course provides the theoretical pre-requisites, the background
and the basis for the design of new structures and the assessment
of existing structures in our built environment. Through the
course, students will acquire knowledge, skills and expertise on
probabilistic modelling, assessment and updating in the fields of
natural hazards, structural information, structural reliability and
risks and ultimately for engineering decisions including the Value
of Information.
learning_objectives:
A student who has met the objectives of the course will be able to:
• Implement decision analyses
• Evaluate engineering decisions before and after
implementation
• Select, determine, verify and update probabilistic models in
the fields of natural hazards, structural information, structural
reliability and risks and engineering decisions
• Select proper analyses tools for structural reliability,
structural risk and decision analyses
• Select appropriate distributions of random variables for
stationary random processes
• Determine limit state functions with basic probabilistic
concepts and definitions
• Perform structural reliability analyses using the First Order
Reliability Method (safety index) and Monte Carlo simulation
• Create and evaluate probabilistic models for structural
information
• Summarize data with numerical and graphical data analysis
• Explain the definition and concept of random variables, vectors
and processes
• Explain the fundamental concepts of reliability and risk based
design and assessment of structures

general_course_objectives:
Main objective is to give the student a general understanding of
the dynamic response of structures loaded by random loadings like,
wind, waves, traffic etc. The focus of the course is on
understanding why the response is nearly always normal distributed,
and that this naturally leads to the use of correlation functions
and spectral densities, and how these quantities should be
understood and estimated from real data. The course is based on
exercises in Matlab.
learning_objectives:
A student who has met the objectives of the course will be able to:
• Define and estimate probabilistic quantities like mean values
and variances from response data
• Define correlation and explain how the concept can be used to
extract physical information
• Define auto-correlation and cross-correlation functions and
explain how they can be used to extract physical information
• Use numerical methods to estimate auto-correlation and
cross-correlation functions
• Explain classical Fourier transforms and use digital Fourier
transforms to process response data in Matlab
• Define spectral density functions and explain how they can be
used to extract physical information
• Use numerical methods to estimate spectral density
functions
• Outline and describe the concept of linear systems and use
Matlab to perform simple response simulations
content:
1. Probalistic description of random responses
2. Correlation and auto correlation functions
3. Cross correlation functions
4. Physical meaning of correlations functions
5. Fourier series and Fourier integral
6. Digital Fourier series
7. Auto spectral density
8. Cross spectral density
9. Response of linear systems
10. Course overview

general_course_objectives:
The course builds on the basic understanding of design of
wood-based element and connections, by introducing orthotropic
mechanical properties of wood and how these properties influence
the design of elements with varying cross-sections and curved
shapes. The course covers advanced topics such as finite element
modelling, built-up elements, fire design, moisture deformations,
and moment- and screwed connections.
learning_objectives:
A student who has met the objectives of the course will be able to:
• Analyze the performance of advanced wooden structures by taking
into account its specific behavior in terms of anisotropy,
strength, rigidity, humidity, load duration, and fire
properties.
• Analyze and calculate timber structural elements with varying
cross-sections and curved shapes.
• Analyze, and devise relevant measures, for the bracing of large
timber frame structures.
• Define and evaluate the impact of serviceability criteria on
the performance of large timber buildings and building
components.
• Define and handle time and moisture dependent effects and loads
on timber structures.
• Analyze complex structures in both solid timber, glulam and
Engineered Wood Products (EWP) using Finite Element software.
• Assess and calculate mechanical connections that are able to
resist large forces and moments.
• Use relevant standards and literature in the design of advanced
wood structures.
• Take part of a design team working with wood
structures.
content:
The course includes an introduction to specific material properties
of wood such as its orthotropic structure, its behavior under
moisture, fire and load duration. Topics covered are instability
problems, displacements, transverse tension/compression, geometries
with varying cross-sections, curved geometries, moisture-related
stresses and deformations, reinforcement of brittle failure modes,
design of moment-resistant and screwed connections, determination
of connection slip and rotational slip modulus, and composite
structures. The course will be a combination of short lectures,
independent study and design work. The design project includes the
determination of loads and calculation of structures based on
relevant standards and literature.

general_course_objectives:
The participants will build knowledge and skills to verify design
and calculate load-bearing structures affected by high temperature
in the form of fully developed and standard fire.
learning_objectives:
A student who has met the objectives of the course will be able to:
• Explain how the expression of a post-flashover fire temperature
can be derived from thermal equilibrium and which parameters the
fire curve depends on.
• List different design fires based on this model and explain the
main differences between nominal fire curves and parametric
fires.
• Calculate the fire characteristics (fuel load, thermal inertia,
and opening factor) of any given compartment and derive the
corresponding parametric fire curve.
• Predict how the variation of the fire characteristics affects
the severity and duration of the fire and, in turn, the heating
temperature and fire resistance of the structural elements.
• Calculate the reduction of the mechanical design load in fire
condition and explain how the mechanical loads influence the
critical temperature and the fire resistance of fire-exposed
structural elements.
• Calculate the reduction of the mechanical properties of steel,
concrete, and wood at high temperatures. Calculate the permanent
reduction of mechanical properties of cold-worked and presstressed
steel and of concrete when they are cooled down to 20 C after being
exposed to high temperatures.
• Perform the design or verification of uninsulated and insulated
steel elements subjected to a parametric or standard fire.
• Perform the verification of timber elements exposed to
parametric or standard fire
• Perform the verification of concrete elemetnts subjected to a
parametric or standard fire during and after the fire.
• Identify possible weaknesses in the structural fire response of
a building elements and indicate measures to improve its fire
resistance.
content:
The course content is divided in 4 main parts, one general on the
structural background and fire action (0.) and three related to the
application of the fire action to the structural design of: 1.
steel, 2. timber, 3. concrete.
0. BACKGROUND ON FIRE AND STRUCTURE (1st module)
Force, moment, static restraints, reactions and external
equilibrium equations. Sectional solicitations and (axial force,
shear, and moment) internal equilibrium equations. Stress, strain,
Hook's elasticity, moment of inertia and elastic modulus of
resistance of a cross-section.
Meaning of flashover assumption in structural fire safety.
Ventilation- and fuel-controlled conditions. Fire characteristics (
Fuel load, ventilation factor, and thermal inertia), DK parametric
fire, standard fire. Fire rating and resistance classes. Mechanical
loads in fire and design methods.
1. STEEL ELEMENT DESIGN (1st and 2nd module)
Thermal properties of steel. Section factor and Biot no. of steel
profiles. Lumped heat capacity method of analysis for uninsulated
steel and derivation of the steel heating temperature curve and
design temp. in fire.
Insulating materials for fire protection of steel elements.
Derivation of design temp. of protected steel under the assumption
of thin insulation (linear temp. gradient in insulation).
Degradation of strength and stiffness of hot-rolled steel.
Calculation of load bearing capacity of unprotected and
fire-protected steel elements (verification) for beams and columns.
Calculation of the min insulation thickness to sustain the imposed
mechanical loads in fire (design) for beams and columns.
Thermal expansion of steel, eigenstresses and reduction of the
capacity of columns with hindered thermal expansion.
2. TIMBER ELEMENT DESIGN (2nd module)
Timber as combustible material. Firestorms and city fires.
Timber as construction material. Charring of wood: charring temp.
and charring rates. Degradation of timber mechanical properties.
Cross-section reduction method and strength reduction method.
Calculation of the load bearing capacity of timber beams and
columns for parametric and standard fire (verification).
Dimensioning of the initial timber cross-sections for given fire
and mechanical loads (design) in simple cases.
Mentions on connections of timber elements and, if time allows,
fire-insulation of timber.
3. CONCRETE ELEMENT DESIGN (3rd module)
Thermal properties of concrete. Type of concrete failures and
examples of collapse. Hot and cold condition.
Concrete temp. for mono- and bi-directional heating. Symmetry lines
and equivalent fully exposed section for temp. calculation at any
given time and depth of any concrete cross-section.
Degradation of mech. properties of concrete and reinforcing steel.
Permanent damage and residual strength. Damage factors (zone
method) and use of CONFIRE.
Calculation of load bearing capacity (verification) of concrete
beams and slabs in bending. Transient strain and axially loaded
columns with no or little eccentricity.

general_course_objectives:
An introduction of the basic terms, principles and methods for
assessment of fire safety of industrial facilities is given.
Hereunder the question about the fire emissions fate and effect in
the environment, as e.g. the impact to nabors. The starting point
are industrial cases and the relevant laws and regualtions, as e.g.
the Seveso and ATEX directives.
learning_objectives:
A student who has met the objectives of the course will be able to:
• Define and describe the basic concepts and terms used in
industrial fire risk assessment
• Interpret physical-chemical and ecotoxicological data for
chemical process in relation to environmental fate and
environmental hazard
• Perform simple quantitative calculations of substance fate
• Collect relevant data on. chemicals, environmental fate and
effects of such Internet and databases
• Classify chemicals in accordance with regulatory guidelines for
risk assessment
• Evaluate preventive and mitigative measures to minimize the
fire and explosion risks
• Plan and carry out a project and formulate hypotheses
• Write a technical report, application of the theory in a
realistic environment problem with chemicals, including drawing
conclusions and making references and citations

content:
Industrielle brande er et vigtig område indenfor vurdering af
brandsikkerhed i bygninger og anlæg. Pga. stor skala processer og
medfølgende lagring af større mængder materialer og kemikalier
ville et brandforløb have en anderledes karakter. Herunder ville
f.eks. større varmestrålingseffekter kunne medføre kaskadeeffekter
og store skader i store afstande, som har potentiale også at
omfatte naboer til industrielle anlæg og kunne medføre miljøskader.
Derudover vil sådanne scenarier vanskeliggøre redningsindsatsen.
Med udgangspunkt i den relevante nationale regulering og lovgivning
baseret på Seveso og Atex direktiverne gennemgås typiske
problemstillinger og afværgeforanstaltninger til at forhindre eller
mindske konsekvenserne til naboer og miljøet.
Kurset introducerer distributionsberegninger af kemikalie- og
brandemissioner. Kursisterne ville kunne forstår og anvende
centrale metoder, som udslips beregninger for væsker og gasser,
beregne jet fires, gaseksplosioner, mv. og anvende Probit
funktioner, til at kunne bedømme personskader.
Særligt vil kursisterne blive indført i miljøkemiske aspekter
omfattende kemiske stoffers udslip, transport, distribution og
nedbrydning i miljøet. Kursisterne vil kunne vurdere akut toksiske
påvirkninger, kroniske påvirkninger og økotoksike påvirkninger.
Datasøgning er herunder et anden vigtig del af kurset og
kursisterne vil lære at anvende forskellige databaser og værktøjer,
som bl.a. DTU's bibliotek stiller til rådighed.
Kurset afsluttes med en skriftlig rapport, hvor kursisten behandler
selvstændig en realistisk situation.

general_course_objectives:
The course introduces the basic concepts and the basic terminology
in fire risk analysis and management. Throughout the course, the
students will acquire:
knowledge on the general approach to fire risk management;
understanding of fundamental probability theory, risk analysis and
decision theory; and be able to perform practical fire risk
assessment. The course will introduce the students to methods for
undertaking a rational fire risk assessment and an ensuing fire
risk management process for the built environment.
learning_objectives:
A student who has met the objectives of the course will be able to:
• Analyze fire risk using a probabilistic method
• Describe physical processes that lead to and are associated
with fires
• Perform an analysis applying Event- and fault trees
• Model stochastic phenomena in fires
• Draw a risk profile and explain the profile
• Assess the advantages associated with different risk reduction
methods related to fire
• Perform a sensitivity analysis based on the students own choice
of relevant parameters
• Perform basic fire risk assessments for a relevant
project/case
• List stochastic input-variables that are related to fire
scenarios in a building
• Readily suggest relevant risk-reducing actions or solutions,
both related to probability and consequence
• Use standard software for probability calculations, risk
analysis and decision analysis
• Obtain input data for a complex fire risk assessment
content:
Based on historical fires of relevance the development of fire risk
assessment is explained. Both deterministic and probabilistic fire
risk methods are introduced. The student will learn about scenario
development analysis for e.g. fire and smoke spread. These
scenarios are combined with evacuation scenarios as well as
acceptance criteria for occupant safety.
The course participant will understand basic probabilistic theory
and perform basic probabilistic calculations. Hereunder, an
introduction to Bayesian Networks and Monte Carlo methods is given.
The differences between qualitative and quantitative risk
assessment are introduced and applied by the participants based on
case studies.

general_course_objectives:
The course is aimed at providing an insight into the most widely
used computational tools for fire and evacuation modeling and their
possible integration in relation to fire safety design.
A student who has met the course objectives, is expected to be able
to:
learning_objectives:
A student who has met the objectives of the course will be able to:
• list the main types of numerical models for pre- and
post-flashover fire
• explain the main set of equations and the main solution methods
of CFD programs
• explain the phenomena influencing evacuation and the analytical
and empirical formula describing them
• explain the main differences between CFD and evacuation
modeling programs and their possible integration implement the
necessary sensitivity analyses on the basis of the main model
assumptions
• identify the main input parameters in FDS and Pathfinder
• highlight the main uncertainties in fire and evacuation models
and implement the necessary sensitivity analyses
• to run analyses in FDS and Pathfinder and interpret the
outcomes
• recognize the main assumptions of the fire and evacuation
models and the limits of validity of the results
content:
The course is organized in three parts, following the schedule of
the classes in three modules of 9h each and focusing on: i)
evacuation modeling; ii) fire modeling; and iii) integration
between the two.
In the first and second modules the main theoretical aspects
related to computational fluid dynamic (CFD) and evacuation
algorithms will be presented, respectively. The syntax of FDS as
CFD program and of Pathfinder as evacuation program will be
introduced and some simple models will be implemented. The
simulations will be aimed at highlighting some critical aspects of
the modeling, such as validation of the model, objectivity of the
solution and sensitivity to uncertainties.
At the end of the first module, the students will be asked to
create an evacuation model in Pathfinder for a given building used
as case study and evaluate the evacuation time. At the end of the
second module, the same case-study will be used as basis for a CFD
model to be implemented in FDS and used to assess the fire
development and tenability criteria.
The assignment will not be graded with a 7-step scala, but on the
basis of a pass/not pass criterion. Passing both assignments is a
requirement to be admitted to the final examination, at the end of
the third module.
In the third module, the two home assignments will be corrected and
the main critical aspects of the modeling will be discussed with
more detail. Few more advanced functions of FDS and Pathfinder will
be introduced and the interaction between fire modeling and
evacuation modeling will be presented. Shorlty after the end of the
third module, a final assignment will be given to the students in
the form of an integrated design problem based on the fire and
evacuation models implemented in the two previous home assignments.
The final models and results should be described in a detailed
report to be submitted by the exam deadline. The evaluation of the
final report will determine whether the students have passed the
course and their grade.

general_course_objectives:
To provide participants with a basic understanding of the

learning_objectives:
A student who has met the objectives of the course will be able to:
• Carry out a performance based design
• Apply knowledge of fire chemistry, fire dynamics and applied
fire safety in the design
• production of a fire strategy report and the corresponding
documentation
• Carry out a senitivity analysis
• Apply knowledge of active fire safety engineering measures
• Carry out evacation calculations
• Choose tenability criteria and document the choice of fire
scenarios
• Couple all criteria to determine critical condition.
• Knowledge of the danish regulation
• Knowledge of the international performance based methods
• Develop a fire safety concept

general_course_objectives:
The aim of the course is to
• introduce the students to analytical methods in relation to
sustainability
• introduce the students to the basic parameters for the design of
sustainable construction
• special focus on the parameters that are not normally included in
usual calculations of sustainability
• special focus on the importance of errors and construction

• special focus on the importance of waste of materials in relation

• special focus on functionality and the use of space in relation

Based on the students' cases, sustainability is analyzed and

learning_objectives:
A student who has met the objectives of the course will be able to:

• Explain and analyze the complexities of sustainability.
• Analyze and identify possible greenwashing.
• Work with building design based on basic parameters for
sustainability.
• Analyze the sustainable elements with a view to identifying

• Discuss the advantages and disadvantages of different
solutions.
• Differentiate between different elements for sustainability
(climate, social, biodiversity etc.), prioritize between these and
integrate them into an overall solution.
• Assess alternatives to make a specific project more
sustainable.
content:
- Parameters for sustainable building design
- The importance of especially the factors that are not included in
calculations and
certifications
- Materials
- Failure, waste, robustness
- Space/area use and building geometry
- Functionality and implementation in practice

general_course_objectives:
The aim of the course is to
introduce the students to an international approach to sustainable
construction, seen in the light of the following:
• an analytical method in relation to sustainability
• the basic parameters for the design of sustainable construction
• special focus on the parameters that are not normally included in

• special focus on the importance of errors and damages in relation
to sustainability
• special focus on the importance of material waste in relation to
sustainability
• special focus on functionality and area utilization in relation
to sustainability
learning_objectives:
A student who has met the objectives of the course will be able to:
• Explain and analyze the complexity of different approaches to
sustainability.
• Explain and analyze methods and solutions used in the study
objects.
• Analyze the objects of study in relation to both the local and
the international context.
• Discuss advantages and disadvantages of the different methods
and solutions.
• Identify possible greenwashing.
• Identify potentials for learning regarding sustainability from
other projects and approaches to the concept.
• Analyze the sustainable elements with a view to identifying
schisms and barriers in the combination of different
initiatives.
• Distinguish between different elements for sustainability
(climate, social, biodiversity, etc.), prioritize between these and
integrate them into an overall solution.
content:
Based on a study tour, the study objectives are analyzed and
processed from the perspective of sustainability in a broad sense
and from a general holistic view.
The students must also expand their international network on
sustainable construction through the study tour.
